   Valves Steam Machine torn down, reveals expensive, well designed, easily upgradable gaming PC | ExtremeTech
  </title>

  <link href="http://mobile.extremetech.com/computing/1036-valveand-8217-s-steam-machine-torn-down-reveals-expensive-well-designed-easily-upgradable-gaming-pc" media="only screen and (max-width: 670px)" rel="alternate"/>
  <meta content="Valves Steam Machine torn down, reveals expensive, well designed, easily upgradable gaming PC | ExtremeTech" property="og:title"/>
  <meta content="ExtremeTech" property="og:site_name"/>
  <meta content="http://www.extremetech.com/gaming/173185-valves-steam-machine-torn-down-reveals-expensive-well-designed-easily-upgradable-gaming-pc" property="og:url"/>
  <meta content="Those dastardly devils at iFixit have managed to get their mitts on one of Valve's 300 Steam Machine prototypes and, of course, torn it down. Inside is a quad-core Haswell Core i5-4570, a Zotac GTX 780 graphics card, 16GB of Crucial Ballistix Sport (PC3 12800) RAM, and a 1TB 5400 RPM Seagate hard drive. If you wanted to build your own SteamOS-powered doppelganger, it would set you back around $1300 to match Valve's Steam Machine part-for-part." property="og:description"/>
  <meta content="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/steam-machine-teardown-top-off.jpg" property="og:image"/>
  <meta content="summary_large_image" name="twitter:card"/>
  <meta content="ExtremeTech" name="twitter:site"/>
  <meta content="@ExtremeTech" name="twitter:creator"/>
  <meta content="extremetech.com" name="twitter:domain"/>
  <meta content="Valves Steam Machine torn down, reveals expensive, well designed, easily upgradable gaming PC | ExtremeTech" name="twitter:title"/>
  <meta content="http://www.extremetech.com/gaming/173185-valves-steam-machine-torn-down-reveals-expensive-well-designed-easily-upgradable-gaming-pc" name="twitter:url"/>
  <meta content="Those dastardly devils at iFixit have managed to get their mitts on one of Valve's 300 Steam Machine prototypes and, of course, torn it down. Inside is a quad-core Haswell Core i5-4570, a Zotac GTX 780 graphics card, 16GB of Crucial Ballistix Sport (PC3 12800) RAM, and a 1TB 5400 RPM Seagate hard drive. If you wanted to build your own SteamOS-powered doppelganger, it would set you back around $1300 to match Valve's Steam Machine part-for-part." name="twitter:description"/>
  <meta content="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/steam-machine-teardown-top-off.jpg" name="twitter:image:src"/>

     <div id="main">
      <div class="add-nav">
       <ul class="breadcrumbs" id="breadcrumbs">
        <!-- Breadcrumb NavXT 5.1.1 -->
        <li class="home">
         <a href="http://www.extremetech.com" title="Go to ExtremeTech.">
          ExtremeTech
         </a>
        </li>
        <li>
         <span typeof="v:Breadcrumb">
          <a class="taxonomy category" href="http://www.extremetech.com/category/computing" property="v:title" rel="v:url" title="Go to the Computing category archives.">

        <li class="current_item">
         Valves Steam Machine torn down, reveals expensive, well designed, easily upgradable gaming PC
        </li>
       </ul>
      </div>
      <div class="twocolumns">
       <div id="content">
        <div class="article">
         <div class="title">
          <h2>
           Valves Steam Machine torn down, reveals expensive, well designed, easily upgradable gaming PC
          </h2>
          <ul>
           <li>
            <span class="by vcard">
             By
             <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/author/santhony" rel="author" title="Posts by Sebastian Anthony">
              Sebastian Anthony
             </a>
             on December 19, 2013 at 1:15 pm
            </span>
           </li>
           <li class="comments">
            <a data-disqus-identifier="173185 http://www.extremetech.com/?p=173185" href="http://www.extremetech.com/gaming/173185-valves-steam-machine-torn-down-reveals-expensive-well-designed-easily-upgradable-gaming-pc#disqus_thread">
             <span>
              Comment
             </span>
            </a>
           </li>
          </ul>
         </div>
         <div class="content">
          <span id="intelliTXT" name="intellitxt">
           <img alt="Tearing open the Steam Machine to find a GTX 780 graphics card" class="attachment-full wp-post-image" height="353" src="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/steam-machine-teardown-top-off-640x353.jpg" width="640"/>
           <div class="photo">
            <div class="box2">
             <h3>
              Share This article
             </h3>
             <div class="addthis_sharing_toolbox">
             </div>
            </div>
           </div>
           <p>
            Those dastardly devils at iFixit have managed to get their mitts on one of Valves 300 Steam Machine prototypes and, of course, torn it down. Inside is a quad-core Haswell Core i5-4570, a Zotac GTX 780 graphics card, 16GB of Crucial Ballistix Sport (PC3 12800) RAM, and a 1TB 5400 RPM Seagate hard drive. If you wanted to build your own SteamOS-powered doppelganger, it would set you back around $1300 to match Valves Steam Machine part-for-part.
           </p>
           <p>
            First and foremost, its good news if you want to repair or upgrade the Steam Machine: The entire thing opens up with the removal of a single Philips screw. Once the upper case is removed, its trivial to replace the hard drive. Remove a custom piece of plastic cowling and you then have access to the GTX 780 graphics card.
           </p>
           <p>
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/steam-machine-inner-cowling.jpg">
             <img alt="Steam Machine, inner cowling protecting the motherboard" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-173197" height="348" src="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/steam-machine-inner-cowling-640x348.jpg" width="640"/>
            </a>
           </p>
           <p>
            Getting at the motherboard and RAM is a little more tricky, however, as it requires the removal of a custom, tightly-fitted plastic cowl. The motherboard is a an ASRock Mini-ITX number (the Z87E), and the Core i5-4570 is cooled by the rather lovely Zalman CNPS 2X cooler. The motherboard, RAM, CPU, and cooler are all completely standard parts  you can replace or upgrade them as you see fit.
           </p>
           <p>
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/steam-machine-motherboard-zalman.jpg">
             <img alt="Steam Machine, ASRock motherboard, Core i5-4570 CPU, and Zalman cooler" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-173193" height="456" src="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/steam-machine-motherboard-zalman-640x456.jpg" width="640"/>
            </a>
           </p>
           <p>
            Beyond that, there isnt much else in Valves Steam Machine. Theres a 450W 80 Plus Gold PSU, and theres a fancy custom logic board harboring 12 LEDs behind The Big Button, and thats about it. iFixit also tore into the Steam Controller, with its two touchpads for thumbsticks, but there isnt a whole lot going on inside. Overall, iFixit gives Valves Steam Machine a nine out of 10 for repairability, losing a point for the difficult-to-remove cowling and precise cable routing that makes it somewhat difficult to put the box back together again.
           </p>
           <p>
            <a href="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/steam-machine-teardown-complete.jpg">
             <img alt="Steam Machine, torn down by iFixit" class="alignnone size-large wp-image-173196" height="527" src="http://www.extremetech.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/12/steam-machine-teardown-complete-640x527.jpg" width="640"/>
            </a>
           </p>
           <p>
            Finally, we should also take this chance to point out the machined holes on top of the Steam Machine. You may have noticed that one of the holes is shiny. In actual fact, there are 320 holes grille holes, and each of the 320 Steam Machine prototypes is uniquely marked by a different shiny hole. According to Valve, 300 Steam Machines were sent out to hardware beta testers, leaving 20 machines to hand out at Valves discretion. Surprisingly, none of the big tech sites seem to have received one, but were hearing that some developers have received them, along with some prominent PC gaming YouTube channels.I find it hard to believe that Valve would give iFixit a Steam Machine purely for tear-down purposes, but who knows. Considering how easy it was to put the Steam Machine back together, its possible that iFixit simply borrowed someones box for a few hours and then gave it back.
           </p>
           <p>
            [Image credit: All images by
            <a href="http://www.ifixit.com/Teardown/Steam+Machine+Teardown/20473">
             iFixit
            </a>
            ]
           </p>
          </span>
         </div>
         <div class="articles-list">
          <div class="holder">
           <div class="widget column widget_execphp" id="execphp-45">
            <div data-page-type="article" data-placement="Below Article Thumbnails - Article -gtd" id="taboola-below-article-thumbnails">
            </div>
            <script type="text/javascript">
             window._taboola = window._taboola || [];
      _taboola.push({
        mode: 'thumbnails-a',
        container: 'taboola-below-article-thumbnails',
        placement: 'Below Article Thumbnails - Article -gtd',
        target_type: 'mix'
      });
            </script>
            <div data-page-type="article" data-placement="Below Article Text Links - Article -gtd" id="taboola-below-article-text-links">
            </div>
            <script type="text/javascript">
             window._taboola = window._taboola || [];
      _taboola.push({
        mode: 'hybrid-text-links-a',
        container: 'taboola-below-article-text-links',
        placement: 'Below Article Text Links - Article -gtd',
        target_type: 'mix'
      });
            </script>
           </div>
          </div>
         </div>
        </div>
        <div class="articles-list">

             </a>
            </span>
            <h3>
             Post a Comment
            </h3>
           </div>

              <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-238539">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-238539">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-238539">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-238539">
                  Phobos
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-238539">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-238539">
                 <p>
                  Hell by the looks of it, the case looks perfect for a HTPC. Might as well install windows, then add the regular steam and get the best of both worlds, instead of getting an OS that just plays games.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
               <ul class="children">
                <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-238556">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-238556">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-238556">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-238556">
                    Stacey Bright
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-238556">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-238556">
                   <p>
                    You probably meant instead of getting an OS that just plays a fraction of the games that are available on windows. SteamOS should theoretically be able to run as a fully functional Linux machine though, so there would be more options to it than games. As far a gaming goes I dont expect much more than what already exists in Linux and Valves first party source engine games. Maybe other developers will hop on board eventually, but thats what Id expect initially.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <ul class="children">
                  <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-238567">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-238567">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-238567">
                     <span id="dsq-author-user-238567">
                      massau
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-238567">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-238567">
                     <p>
                      i would like it if they jumped to linux but than i hope that linux will get a standard install folder like program files folder in linux. because if you want to tweak / mod the game then you have to find the program files which is harder to do in linux.
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                   <ul class="children">
                    <li class="comment even depth-4" id="dsq-comment-238659">
                     <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-238659">
                      <cite id="dsq-cite-238659">
                       <span id="dsq-author-user-238659">
                        squirrelboy
                       </span>
                      </cite>
                     </div>
                     <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-238659">
                      <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-238659">
                       <p>
                        /home/.local/share/steam/   (steamapps/common/)
                       </p>
                       <p>
                        or you could go /home/.steam/ and there is a shortcut to /home/.local/share/steam/ in that folder. ctrl+h makes hidden folders (with a . in front of the name) visible.
                        <br/>
                        /home/ is comparable to program files. most installed programs gets a hidden folder in there.
                       </p>
                      </div>
                     </div>
                    </li>
                    <!-- #comment-## -->
                   </ul>
                   <!-- .children -->
                  </li>
                  <!-- #comment-## -->
                  <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-238585">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-238585">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-238585">
                     <span id="dsq-author-user-238585">
                      Phobos
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-238585">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-238585">
                     <p>
                      not just a fraction, but what else does it do? It seems that its trying to compete with consoles, but with no exclusive titles as Valve has stated that they are not interested in exclusive titles so what kind of appeal will it have then? I guess just to Linux users who want an alternative play other than windows.
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                   <ul class="children">
                    <li class="comment even depth-4" id="dsq-comment-238703">
                     <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-238703">
                      <cite id="dsq-cite-238703">
                       <span id="dsq-author-user-238703">
                        Scott Jackson
                       </span>
                      </cite>
                     </div>
                     <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-238703">
                      <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-238703">
                       <p>
                        Youre missing one of the main selling points of it, which is that it can stream Windows games. The main idea is to be able to bring PC gaming to your living room to play on you big HDTV instead of moving your current PC or running long wires. You can play any Windows Steam game on your Steambox, however if you are just planning to stream games from a powerful PC to your Steambox then you dont need the beefy specs of this setup because it would just serve as a receiver to your streaming data with your Windows PC doing the heavy lifting.
                       </p>
                      </div>
                     </div>
                     <ul class="children">
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-238710">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-238710">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-238710">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-238710">
                          Phobos
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-238710">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-238710">
                         <p>
                          So the selling point is just to stream?? That will be terrible and expensive. Might as well plug my pc to my tv and save bandwidth and money.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-238716">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-238716">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-238716">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-238716">
                          Scott Jackson
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-238716">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-238716">
                         <p>
                          One of the selling points, along with the dedicated gaming SteamOS and Steam controller, and also the hardware could be cheaper than building it yourself. Yes you could just plug your PC into your TV and save the money, which is why the Steambox has had its fair share of critics, but not everyone wants to move their PC.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-238820">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-238820">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-238820">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-238820">
                          Stacey Bright
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-238820">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-238820">
                         <p>
                          How is that a selling point? If it is still costly solution using 2 full computers to do the job of 1 computer. Between still paying for what a entry level gaming computer costs, and the cost in electricity running them both. If running wires is a problem for someone, we then have to assume this streaming is going to be done over wireless which I see potentially inducing latency. This might not be a problem depending on the type of game to be played, but if thats good enough then there are wireless display and input options that would prove cheaper still and more energy efficient. Im seeing less and less value here.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-238872">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-238872">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-238872">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-238872">
                          Scott Jackson
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-238872">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-238872">
                         <p>
                          Yes those are valid points. If the streaming capability is going to work at all minimal latency is a must. Also, having two gaming PCs yes would be both costly and impractical. It is kind of puzzling to me that they are making this high-end Steam machines that can run any game by themselves but also trying to sell the whole streaming capability. Do you want it to be a gaming PC or basically like a roku or chromecast but for gaming? Seems like they are trying to have their cake and eat it too. I dont think people are gonna buy these expensive Steam machines and then be willing to have another windows gaming PC to stream they games the Steam machine cant run natively. And I am not advocating that the Steam machine is necessarily a good idea, just pointing out its supposed selling points.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-238898">

                    <!-- #comment-## -->
                    <li class="comment even depth-4" id="dsq-comment-238821">
                     <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-238821">
                      <cite id="dsq-cite-238821">
                       <span id="dsq-author-user-238821">
                        Stacey Bright
                       </span>
                      </cite>
                     </div>
                     <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-238821">
                      <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-238821">
                       <p>
                        Well if its basically an X86 debian linux box, then it could potentially access a repository of endless open source alternatives to windows applications. So basically roughly as functional as a windows computer in everything but gaming ironically. That really relies on the end-user being comfortable with both linux, its alternative applications, and not having or desiring a PC already running windows or linux. That other potential capability means youll be hooking up a keyboard and mouse anyway. It cant properly compete against consoles or other PCs. So its only real option it just to try and exist, perhaps in its own little bubble, like Apple.
                       </p>
                      </div>
                     </div>
                     <ul class="children">
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-238873">

                         </p>

                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-239082">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-239082">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-239082">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-239082">
                          IKROWNI
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-239082">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-239082">
                         <p>
                          How does it not compete with consoles? The price is around that of consoles. It can run windows instead if you wish. Its upgradeable. Games are cheaper. No subs. Much much better graphics, resolution, fps, the list goes on and on. There is literally nothing the consoles have better than this machine at all.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-239292">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-239292">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-239292">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-239292">
                          Stacey Bright
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-239292">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-239292">
                         <p>
                          Ill start off by clarifying that Im definitely a PC gamer all the way, though I own a PS3. However for the target market of console gamers, the things that make PC gaming superior are of no consequence. You may also be misinterpreting the context by which I use compete. Mostly as in it doesnt compete with consoles (for business), because its clearly not meant to. Youre still looking at $300-400 more than a console. Games are not cheaper, not the AAA titles at launch anyway. The subs you speak of arent exactly mandatory and youre only hampered by not having one on the XBOX platform.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Then there are the exclusives, or temporary exclusive deals that keep a game from coming to PC for 6+ months after the console release. Oh and the ever so wonderful porting process weve all come to love so much in the past. The only thing I honestly appreciate about this gen of consoles is the X86-64 architecture, and its potential benefits to PC ports. The steam box however only has any benefit to those generally opposed to consoles (PC gamers), but doesnt already have a PC. Which in and of itself is quite contradictory.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          At best Valve could use the Steam Box as a means of becoming a PC OEM, providing affordable gaming machines. Every other gaming PC vendor explicitly targets the high-end enthusiast market. This actually creates the concept among your typical console gamer that in order to switch to PC gaming they need an Alienware. I see the existence of the Steam Box potentially fixing that misconception. For everyone else in the know we are already building our own machines.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-240935">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-240935">

                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-242384">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-242384">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-242384">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-242384">
                          Stacey Bright
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-242384">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-242384">
                         <p>
                          Funny you mention COD specifically, seeing as at launch its $60 across all platforms. Yeah there are sales on PC titles, eventually, but all games get cheaper eventually. Many of Top tier publishers have been releasing games at console prices on PC for a while now. Starcraft 2 (PC exclusive) remained at $60 what seemed like forever. BF4 PC is $60 on amazon right now. My statement was about asking price at launch, particularly involving AAA titles. Not even steam discounts a very recently released game during their sale periods. There was a time when you could expect the PC version of a multi-platform game to be $10 cheaper, but long gone are those days.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-242400">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-242400">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-242400">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-242400">
                          Bad Conduct
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-242400">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-242400">
                         <p>
                          BF4 was already at 29.99 during black friday on Origin. Blizzard never discounts their games, but thats a stupid comparison considering its PC only at this time. There any many console exclusives in the same price range.
                          <br/>
                          Its the fact that, on Steam at least, downloadable PC titles often get heavy discounts. Console games on the shelves do not.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-242419">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-242419">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-242419">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-242419">
                          Stacey Bright
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-242419">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-242419">
                         <p>
                          Yeah I missed that BF4 thing since Im not fully onboard with Origin. Im skipping it just like I did with BF3 anyway. Actually Im pretty sure it supports my point with Blizzard with all the BS behind why console games are $60, for what reason should a PC only title be that price as well. Im Activision in general lead the charge with upping PC prices anyway. I never said steam doesnt discount at all. Ive repeatedly mentioned that Im arguing original asking prices at launch. So if a game came out yesterday on PC with an original price of $60 in the middle of a steam sale, that game is still going to $60 probably at least until the next sale. That game would probably be in the COD series.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Then there is the fact that not everyone is comfortable with or even capable of relying on digital distribution. Those same PC games on shelves dont see those discounts either. There are still people that prefer physical copies, or just dont want to wait either for a download or an undetermined sale period of a specific title. The $60 price tag on console realistically works so well due to crowd mentality. Everyone wants to play it as soon as its out, because they know everyone will be playing it as soon as its out.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          The publishers try as much as they can to pull the same thing on PC versions but the install base really isnt as high as console. Otherwise they just pull a Rockstar and just delay the PC release long enough that most have settled on the console version. Actually you do have the option of cheaper console games on shelves, its called USED. The same crowd that doesnt buy PC games at launch to wait on a sale are of the same type that specifically wait for the used console titles. The same companies that would try to kill the used game market would just as soon want PC gaming dead.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-242509">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-242509">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-242509">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-242509">
                          Bad Conduct
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-242509">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-242509">
                         <p>
                          What do you mean, pull the same thing?
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          These games have million dollar development budgets. If they are not profitable, they wont get investments and they wont create sequels or even risk developing a new title.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          And you are right, PC games on the shelves dont get discounted, nor can they be traded in or loaned.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Im just saying, it will go on sale on Steam within 6 months, even for only 10% off, long before the console version takes a price drop. PC gaming is cheaper, because its digitally distributed. Being ignorant of where to find the best price does not mean its equally priced. It just means youre either not looking for deals, or want the game on release date.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>

                         </p>
                         <p>
                          And you are right, PC games on the shelves dont get discounted, nor can they be traded in or loaned.
                         </p>
                         <p>
                          Im just saying, it will go on sale on Steam within 6 months, even for only 10% off, long before the console version takes a price drop. PC gaming is cheaper, because its digitally distributed. Being ignorant of where to find the best price does not mean its equally priced. It just means youre either not looking for deals, or want the game on release date.

                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-243451">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-243451">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-243451">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-243451">
                          Stacey Bright
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-243451">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-243451">
                         <p>
                          At some point it was decided to in the industry to raise the base price of games by $10 because the market would bear it. Its not like the $50 cost wasnt profitable, its about getting even more profit where they can.Gaming in general should theoretically be cheaper with digital distribution. Are referring to it being cheaper to manufacture, or cheaper for the consumer, because the two end up being mutually exclusive. Console titles also have the option of digital distribution. My argument still stands as  on sale within 6 months has no bearing on the fact that the original MSRP of $60 exists on all platforms regardless of distribution method.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment even depth-5" id="dsq-comment-243478">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-243478">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-243478">

                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-243478">

Or when PC games are released for 10$ less on Steam, or have a pre-release 10% off, or go on sale in less than 6 months (which often happens), THAN PC games are the same price. Which is not very often.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>
                      </li>
                      <!-- #comment-## -->
                      <li class="comment odd alt depth-5" id="dsq-comment-381198">
                       <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-381198">
                        <cite id="dsq-cite-381198">
                         <span id="dsq-author-user-381198">
                          Joshua
                         </span>
                        </cite>
                       </div>
                       <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-381198">
                        <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-381198">
                         <p>
                          Console gaming is by far cheaper, most gaming PCs are above $1000.  The argument that you could build a better gaming PC than a console for about the same price is pointless, because no one does that.  People spend upwards of a grand on the graphics cards alone, and you wanna say PC gaming is cheaper?  PC games can be cheaper then console games, but they usually dont sell as well as their console versions.  Console gamers spend more money on games wheras PC gamers spend more money on equipment.  Even then, with console gamers spending more money on games than PC gamers its still cheaper to game on a console.
                         </p>
                        </div>
                       </div>

              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-238561">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-238561">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-238561">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-238561">
                  Blasian
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-238561">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-238561">
                 <p>
                  Exactly how upgradable are these things? Would it mean that I only need to buy this thing once and then continually upgrade as needed years later? Or will there be a time when I will have to (like consoles) purchase a new one?
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Im debating whether to save money for this or build my own PC (which im leaning towards because i can use it for things other than gaming)
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
               <ul class="children">
                <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-238564">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-238564">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-238564">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-238564">
                    massau
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-238564">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-238564">
                   <p>
                    i think you can put all graphics cards in it as you like but it cant be larger than the GTX780, the motherboard looks like a ITX or mini ATX so you could just upgrade it al long as you stay within power budget and find a round cooler for the cpu.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <ul class="children">
                  <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-238656">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-238656">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-238656">
                     <span id="dsq-author-user-238656">
                      Turo Orvel
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-238656">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-238656">
                     <p>
                      There is a lot of room under the gpu so it probably fits one that have a bigger custom cooler.
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                  </li>
                  <!-- #comment-## -->
                 </ul>
                 <!-- .children -->
                </li>
                <!-- #comment-## -->
                <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-239092">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-239092">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-239092">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-239092">
                    IKROWNI
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-239092">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-239092">
                   <p>
                    It would depend on your preference. If you go with your own build you can get a case that is a bit larger that way you can keep adding more hard drives, use crossfire/sli, more ports, blah blah blah. With this you wouldnt have room for xfire/sli and it doesnt seem to have room for extra hard drives. This wouldnt be as open as your own build and would cost you more money down the road.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Think of it this way would you rather spend $100 and grab a 3tb HDD to replace the drive you have when its full? Or would you rather just slide in another to use together?
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    Would you rather sell your old GPU and buy a new one or save a bit of cash and buy an identical card to the one you have and expand its life that way?
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    But dont get me wrong some would rather have the small console sized form than the easier upgrading.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    I would say steam machines should appeal more to people who want a set it and forget it small sized machine that games in great quality compared to consoles without all the locked up shit the consoles provide.
                   </p>
                   <p>
                    I love where steam is going with this and I understand what there intention is. They want to allow people an easy transition from something inferior to something with true power. They had to make it look similar and be super easy to just turn on grab controller and play. Then after the person making the transition sees what they were truelly missing out on they will notice the freedoms they have and will explore more and more into it turning them from peasant to master race.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <ul class="children">
                  <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-239146">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-239146">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-239146">

                      antano
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-239146">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-239146">
                     <p>
                      Id put a 256+ SSD and external HDD.
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                  </li>
                  <!-- #comment-## -->

              <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-238566">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-238566">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-238566">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-238566">
                  VirtualMark
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-238566">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-238566">
                 <p>
                  It looks like a nice piece of kit, lets hope the prices is acceptable.  Id like one for a living room PC.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-238576">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-238576">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-238576">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-238576">
                  Dozerman
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-238576">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-238576">
                 <p>
                  Okay, so how much will this cost and what is the point? If its highly subsidized and costs 800 dollars, it is still over double a PS4, albeit probably four times more powerful.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  I think the point in the Valve-built steam machines isnt as a competitive console, and more as a proof of concept. I mean, seriously; 16 gigs of ram? What sane console maker would put 16 gigs of ram in a console?
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Its gonna be much more interesting to me to watch the battle play out at the low end where the consoles lie. Give it a year of progression, and PC parts will be cheaper and faster that what is in the PS4 and XBO. At that point, itll be a race to the bottom between the consoles and SteamMachine.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
               <ul class="children">
                <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-238725">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-238725">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-238725">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-238725">
                    Kevin Moore
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-238725">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-238725">
                   <p>
                    I dont think they are trying to compete with consoles for right now. I think they are trying to offer an alternative to the group of PC gamers who would rather buy a console than fiddle with trying to hook up their PC to the living room. They are also presenting technology that if it takes off will give them a huge lead and could potentially skyrocket them into the console market. That being streaming windows games and easily swappable/upgradeable hardware that can still be optimized for by developers.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </li>
                <!-- #comment-## -->
                <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-238968">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-238968">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-238968">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-238968">
                    pixelstuff
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-238968">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-238968">
                   <p>
                    Maybe after a few high end games are developed that maximize its ability, they plan to release a second mid-range console with the performance matched to the PS4 and Xbox One, then say, hey look at how under powered the competition is. Now go buy a top tier SteamBox and do some cutting edge gaming.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <ul class="children">
                  <li class="comment odd alt depth-3" id="dsq-comment-239093">
                   <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-239093">
                    <cite id="dsq-cite-239093">
                     <span id="dsq-author-user-239093">
                      IKROWNI
                     </span>
                    </cite>
                   </div>
                   <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-239093">
                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-239093">
                     <p>
                      Source engine 2 is coming soon. Titanfall uses source engine 1 and that engine was created by valve in 1997. At least valve knows that next gen games wont be built on engines from 16 years ago for hardware from 5 years ago. Valve said they dont believe in the exclusives crap the console manufacturers try to play as a good thing. They will be bringing there games to most platforms, the problem will lie with the consoles though. Expect for real next gen games to have major issues playing on inferior hardware.
                     </p>
                    </div>
                   </div>
                  </li>

              <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-238702">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-238702">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-238702">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-238702">
                  Choking Kojak
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-238702">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-238702">
                 <p>
                  I hate to say it but Im impressed with this Steam Machine.  I dont need one, though  I put together a desktop a few years back, now fitted with newer cards that keep it in shape  for any PC game on the market right now
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Heres the problem, though  Like I said, I am impressed with the Steam Machine.
                  <br/>
                  I like it Unfortunately, though, when I like something, it means that nobody or few others are going to like it.
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  As such, the Steam Machines is probably going to be a total sales disaster for Steam.
                  <br/>
                  If I hated it, though, itd be a monster success for Steam.    Im sorry Steam.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
               <ul class="children">

                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                 <ul class="children">
                  <li class="comment even depth-3" id="dsq-comment-238758">

                     </p>

                     </p>

                     </p>

              <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-238731">

                 </p>

               <ul class="children">
                <li class="comment even depth-2" id="dsq-comment-238792">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-238792">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-238792">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-238792">
                    Dave Harnett
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-238792">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-238792">
                   <p>
                    The board has got mSATA and SRT support  an ssd cache could be a popular 50 upgrade. Spending hundreds on an ssd big enough to act as the primary drive would be overkill for all but the most spendy enthusiasts, particularly when the 16gb ram should allow for lots of pre-caching.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </li>

                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Funny thing is I and probably many of us reading this have been using the PC as a media center since 2006.                  </p>

                    <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-239258">
                     <p>
                      I am actually a very nice guy in person(probably one of the nicest guys on this planet), but I wont tolerate bullcrap being thrown at my face. I am sure you dont either.               <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-239247">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-239247">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-239247">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-239247">
                  Nicolas Edwards
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-239247">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-239247">
                 <p>
                  Does not seem to be any diffrent than any other console or computer rig.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-239349">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-239349">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-239349">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-239349">
                  James Tolson
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-239349">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-239349">
                 <p>
                  this is where in my opinion the steam box fails.. if the goal of valve is to create a standard platform that all games should run perfectly on then basing it on a standard PC hardware is never the way to go.. because next years games will struggle to run on it and the following years will not.. this then completely obsoletes the hardware.. what im dubious about is the business model? as anyone who ever reads my comments knows im ANTI drm/dlc microtransaction scams and landfill devise e waste scams the whole industry is now following since Apple led the way.. so this is the reason it will FAIL, People must surly by know see that getting roped into a product only to have Valve Steambox 2.0 dangled like a carrot 12 months later, then steambox 2s then 3 then 3s and so on and so on is borderline outrageous  and hopefully the general consumer will bow out of their naivety like me and say im out before the first ever steambox goes on sale.. it makes much more sense to me just to build a general gaming pc and then install steam os on that.. but that in itself has its pitfalls.. no new game interests me anyway except maybe Elite dangerous and maybe might magic 10 but if i cannot run them on my current setup then im afraid i wont be playing them at all..
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment odd alt thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-239464">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-239464">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-239464">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-239464">
                  D.B.
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-239464">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-239464">
                 <p>
                  I would have loved to see a more special case, something STEAMpunk or if not then more futuristic or minimalistic elegant desing. Not a black box with many tiny holes :(. I hope is just a prototype. As for price, is obvious it will be in the range of latest gen consoles even if that means they will lose money at first, and untill will come out the price will drop at least 20% on each component, thats for sure.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment even thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-240496">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-240496">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-240496">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-240496">
                  Izzy Rallins
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-240496">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-240496">
                 <p>
                  They put a 5400RPM hard drive in there? are they mad? That will slow down the whole system. Booting up, loading, texture swapping and the FAILURE RATES of 2.5 hard drives! yuck!
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Although, with the way nVidia is ripping people off for video cards ($240 for a card that is powerful enough to beat my old old GTX260 which was $180 4 yrs ago) it might be worth buying this just to get a GTX 780 and all those other components for cheap.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
               <ul class="children">
                <li class="comment odd alt depth-2" id="dsq-comment-242903">
                 <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-242903">
                  <cite id="dsq-cite-242903">
                   <span id="dsq-author-user-242903">
                    Mark
                   </span>
                  </cite>
                 </div>
                 <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-242903">
                  <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-242903">
                   <p>
                    Its actually Seagates SSHD (a hybrid SSD) if you take a look at the iFixit teardown. Most reviewers agree that SSHDs are the best price/performance trade off at the moment.
                   </p>
                  </div>
                 </div>
                </li>
                <!-- #comment-## -->
               </ul>
               <!-- .children -->
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-240497">
               <div class="dsq-comment-header" id="dsq-comment-header-240497">
                <cite id="dsq-cite-240497">
                 <span id="dsq-author-user-240497">
                  Izzy Rallins
                 </span>
                </cite>
               </div>
               <div class="dsq-comment-body" id="dsq-comment-body-240497">
                <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-240497">
                 <p>
                  They put a 5400RPM hard drive in there? are they mad? That will slow down the whole system. Booting up, loading, texture swapping and the FAILURE RATES of 2.5 hard drives! yuck!
                 </p>
                 <p>
                  Although, with the way nVidia is ripping people off for video cards ($240 for a card that is powerful enough to beat my old old GTX260 which was $180 4 yrs ago) it might be worth buying this just to get a GTX 780 and all those other components for cheap.
                 </p>
                </div>
               </div>
              </li>
              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment odd alt thread-odd thread-alt depth-1" id="dsq-comment-293330">

                 </p>

              <!-- #comment-## -->
              <li class="comment even thread-even depth-1" id="dsq-comment-319699">

                 </p>

              <!-- #comment-## -->
             </ul>
            </div>
           </div>
           <script type="text/javascript">
            /* &lt;![CDATA[ */
    var disqus_url = 'http://www.extremetech.com/gaming/173185-valves-steam-machine-torn-down-reveals-expensive-well-designed-easily-upgradable-gaming-pc';
    var disqus_identifier = '173185 http://www.extremetech.com/?p=173185';
    var disqus_container_id = 'disqus_thread';
    var disqus_domain = 'disqus.com';
    var disqus_shortname = 'extremetech';
    var disqus_title = "Valve&#8217;s Steam Machine torn down, reveals expensive, well designed, easily upgradable gaming PC";
        var disqus_config = function () {
        var config = this; // Access to the config object
        config.language = '';

        /*
           All currently supported events:
            * preData  fires just before we request for initial data
            * preInit - fires after we get initial data but before we load any dependencies
            * onInit  - fires when all dependencies are resolved but before dtpl template is rendered
            * afterRender - fires when template is rendered but before we show it
            * onReady - everything is done
         */

        config.callbacks.preData.push(function() {
            // clear out the container (its filled for SEO/legacy purposes)
            document.getElementById(disqus_container_id).innerHTML = '';
        });
                config.callbacks.onReady.push(function() {
            // sync comments in the background so we don't block the page
            var script = document.createElement('script');
            script.async = true;
            script.src = '?cf_action=sync_comments&amp;post_id=173185';

            var firstScript = document.getElementsByTagName( "script" )[0];
            firstScript.parentNode.insertBefore(script, firstScript);
        });
                    };
/* ]]&gt; */
           </script>
           <script type="text/javascript">
            /* &lt;![CDATA[ */
    var DsqLocal = {
        'trackbacks': [
        ],
        'trackback_url': "http:\/\/www.extremetech.com\/gaming\/173185-valves-steam-machine-torn-down-reveals-expensive-well-designed-easily-upgradable-gaming-pc\/trackback"    };
/* ]]&gt; */
           </script>
           <script type="text/javascript">
            /* &lt;![CDATA[ */
(function() {
    var dsq = document.createElement('script'); dsq.type = 'text/javascript';
    dsq.async = true;
    dsq.src = '//' + disqus_shortname + '.' + 'disqus.com' + '/embed.js?pname=wordpress&amp;pver=2.74';
    (document.getElementsByTagName('head')[0] || document.getElementsByTagName('body')[0]).appendChild(dsq);
})();
/* ]]&gt; */
           </script>
          </div>

     <div class="footer-frame">
      <div class="content">
       <div class="widget column widget_execphp" id="execphp-46">
        <script type="text/javascript">
         window._taboola = window._taboola || [];
    _taboola.push({flush: true});
    
    var __ZDTABEVENT = {
        accountid : "",
        init : function(acct) {
            __ZDTABEVENT.accountid = acct;
            var divs = document.querySelectorAll("div[id^=taboola]"), i=divs.length;
            while (i--) {
                divs[i].addEventListener("click", __ZDTABEVENT.clkevt);
                __ZDTABEVENT.track(divs[i].id, "imp");
            }
        },
        clkevt : function(evt){
            __ZDTABEVENT.track(evt.currentTarget.id, "clk");


        },
        track : function(id,evt) {
            var el = document.getElementById(id);
            var placement = el.getAttribute('data-placement');
            var pagetype = el.getAttribute('data-page-type');
            if(window.ga) window.ga('send', 'event', 'Taboola', pagetype + '-' + placement, evt);
            if(window._gaq) window._gaq.push(['_trackEvent', 'Taboola', pagetype+'-'+placement, evt, undefined, true]);
            if (__ZDDMP) { __ZDDMP.Event({signal:'taboola', pubid: __ZDTABEVENT.accountid, ptype:pagetype, placement:placement, evt:evt});}
        }
    };
    __ZDTABEVENT.init('ziffdavis-network15-extremetech');
        </script>
       </div>

        <script type="text/javascript">
         var _sf_async_config = _sf_async_config || {};
/** CONFIGURATION START **/
&lt;!-- set in head --&gt;
_sf_async_config.sections = 'Computing'; 
_sf_async_config.authors ='Sebastian Anthony';
/** CONFIGURATION END **/
(function(){
function loadChartbeat()
{ window._sf_endpt=(new Date()).getTime(); var e = document.createElement('script'); e.setAttribute('language', 'javascript'); e.setAttribute('type', 'text/javascript'); e.setAttribute('src', '//static.chartbeat.com/js/chartbeat.js'); document.body.appendChild(e); }

var oldonload = window.onload;
window.onload = (typeof window.onload != 'function') ?
loadChartbeat : function()
{ oldonload(); loadChartbeat(); }

;
})();
        </script>

        <script type="text/javascript">
         jQuery(document).ready(function() {
  setTimeout(function() {
  if (jQuery("#adsense").height() &lt; 8) { 
    if (window._gaq) { window._gaq.push(['_trackEvent', 'AdBlocker','Blocked' ,undefined, undefined, true]); }
    if (window.ga) { window.ga('send', 'event', 'AdBlocker', 'Blocked'); }
  } else {
    if (window._gaq) { window._gaq.push(['_trackEvent', 'AdBlocker','NotBlocked' ,undefined, undefined, true]); }
    if (window.ga) { window.ga('send', 'event', 'AdBlocker', 'NotBlocked' ); }
    }
	}, 2000);
});
        </script>

  <script type="text/javascript">
   // &lt;![CDATA[
        var disqus_shortname = 'extremetech';
        (function () {
            var nodes = document.getElementsByTagName('span');
            for (var i = 0, url; i &lt; nodes.length; i++) {
                if (nodes[i].className.indexOf('dsq-postid') != -1) {
                    nodes[i].parentNode.setAttribute('data-disqus-identifier', nodes[i].getAttribute('rel'));
                    url = nodes[i].parentNode.href.split('#', 1);
                    if (url.length == 1) url = url[0];
                    else url = url[1]
                    nodes[i].parentNode.href = url + '#disqus_thread';
                }
            }
            var s = document.createElement('script'); s.async = true;
            s.type = 'text/javascript';
            s.src = '//' + 'disqus.com/forums/' + disqus_shortname + '/count.js';
            (document.getElementsByTagName('HEAD')[0] || document.getElementsByTagName('BODY')[0]).appendChild(s);
        }());
    //]]&gt;
  </script>
